basics.name: MD ATIQUR RAHMAN
basics.summary: Enthusiastic Lecturer in Computer Science and Engineering with a passion for research in computer vision and a strong interest in competitive programming. Continuously striving to improve problem-solving skills, actively engages in challenging tasks and projects to push personal and professional limits. Dedicated to inspiring students through impactful teaching and fostering innovation in computing and engineering.

work.name: United International University

work.summary: Taking coordinated classes and labs of CSE students and providing after class sessions to help students who have issues understanding the covered topics.

publications.name: FUSED-Net: Enhancing Few-Shot Traffic Sign Detection with Unfrozen Parameters, Pseudo-Support Sets, Embedding Normalization, and Domain Adaptation
publications.summary: Automatic Traffic Sign Recognition is paramount in modern transportation systems, motivating several research endeavors to focus on performance improvement by utilizing large-scale datasets. As the appearance of traffic signs varies across countries, curating large-scale datasets is often impractical; and requires efficient models that can produce satisfactory performance using limited data. In this connection, we present 'FUSED-Net', built-upon Faster RCNN for traffic sign detection, enhanced by Unfrozen Parameters, Pseudo-Support Sets, Embedding Normalization, and Domain Adaptation while reducing data requirement.

projects.name: Few Shot Bangladeshi Traffic Sign Detector
projects.summary: Formulating an object detection model utilizing domain adaptation, pseudo support set, Embedded Normalization and Unfrozen Parameters concept to achieve comparatively better results than some SOTA architectures.

projects.name: Bench-marking GTSRB for Few Shot Learning
projects.summary: Bench-marking GTSRB utilizing metric-based few shot classifiers e.g. BDCSPN, PrototypicalNet, RelationNet, TransductiveFinetune.

projects.name: Federated Organ-agnostic Tumor Segmentation
projects.summary: Leveraging the U-Net architecture as both the global and local model in the FedAVG algorithm for tumor segmentation in two organs: the breast and the brain.
